descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: The course will cover topics such as international capital flows, the determination of exchange rates, currency and sovereign debt crises. The objective is to help students think clearly about these issues using simple economic models. While a significant portion of the course will be theoretical, there will be several occasions for linking the theory to real-world events.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Econ 201, 202, 281, 310-1, 311, Math 220, Stats 210. Students are expected to be comfortable with basic differential calculus.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two lectures a week, plus a possible TA session.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: At least one midterm and a final, which will together count for at least 50% of the final grade. The remainder will come from assignments, the number of which will depend on the size of the class.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: For the most part, we will use two sources: i) International Finance: Theory and Policy (tenth edition), by P. Krugman, M. Obstfeld and M. Melitz; ISBN-13: 978-0133423631; ii) International Macroeconomics, by S. Schmitt-Grohe', M. Uribe and M.Woodford (downloadable online). These textbooks will be integrated with assigned readings from other sources, such as articles and supplementary notes.
